[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: process_dependency()] [Skip Fetch Exploitation] When skip_fetch_latest_git_deps is true, git updates are skipped - can an attacker exploit this to use stale vulnerable dependencies by manipulating the skip flag in production builds? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: process_dependency()] [Resolution Table Leak] The function returns dep's resolution_table by clone - can an attacker exploit shared Rc references to modify addresses in the returned table, affecting other packages that share the same named addresses? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: process_dependency()] [Context Error Injection] Error contexts include dep_name_in_pkg from user input - can an attacker inject format string specifiers or escape sequences that exploit logging frameworks when errors are written? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: parse_package_manifest()] [Path Traversal] When pushing dep.local to root_path, can an attacker provide a dep.local value with ../ sequences that escape the root directory, accessing arbitrary filesystem locations? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: parse_package_manifest()] [Symbolic Link Following] If dep.local points to a symbolic link, can an attacker use symlinks to redirect manifest reading to attacker-controlled files outside the package directory? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: parse_package_manifest()] [Manifest Injection] When reading manifest with fs::read_to_string(), can an attacker provide extremely large manifests (gigabytes) that cause memory exhaustion when loaded into a String? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: parse_package_manifest()] [TOCTOU Race] Between checking file existence with fs::read_to_string() and parsing, can an attacker replace the manifest file with malicious content, bypassing any previous validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: parse_package_manifest()] [Parser Exploitation] The parse_move_manifest_string() and parse_source_manifest() are chained - can an attacker craft manifests that exploit vulnerabilities in these parsers, causing crashes or code execution? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: parse_package_manifest()] [Error Message Path Disclosure] Error messages include full filesystem paths via root_path.join() - can this leak sensitive information about validator node directory structure? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: download_and_update_if_remote()] [Git URL Injection] When git_info.git_url.as_str() is passed to git operations, can an attacker inject command-line arguments or special characters that execute arbitrary git commands? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: download_and_update_if_remote()] [Git Rev Manipulation] Can an attacker provide a git_rev that appears to be a commit hash but is actually a malicious branch name or tag that gets executed as a shell command during checkout? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: download_and_update_if_remote()] [Download Path Traversal] The git_info.download_to path is used without validation - can an attacker provide paths with ../ that cause git to clone repositories into arbitrary directories like /etc or /bin? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: download_and_update_if_remote()] [Cache Poisoning] When checking if download_to.exists(), can an attacker pre-populate the cache directory with malicious code before the build, bypassing the fresh git clone? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: download_and_update_if_remote()] [Skip Fetch Attack] When skip_fetch_latest_git_deps is true and cached version exists, updates are skipped - can an attacker exploit this to use vulnerable cached dependencies in production by manipulating cache state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: download_and_update_if_remote()] [Rev Parsing Bypass] The code checks if git_rev is a commit using find_rev() - can an attacker craft a rev string that appears to be a commit hash to this check but resolves to a different commit during actual checkout? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: download_and_update_if_remote()] [Tag Immutability Assumption] The code assumes tags don't change and skips updates - can an attacker exploit force-push to tags to update malicious code without triggering re-fetch? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: download_and_update_if_remote()] [Fetch Origin Manipulation] When calling git::fetch_origin(), can an attacker perform a man-in-the-middle attack during fetch to inject malicious commits that appear to come from the legitimate origin? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: download_and_update_if_remote()] [Reset Hard Data Loss] The git::reset_hard() operation discards local changes - can an attacker exploit this to destroy legitimate code modifications or trigger unintended repository states? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: download_and_update_if_remote()] [Custom Node Hook] When dep.node_info is Some(), package_hooks::resolve_custom_dependency() is called - can an attacker exploit this hook mechanism to execute arbitrary code during dependency resolution? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: unify_addresses_in_package()] [Address Override Attack] When unifying addresses from package.addresses, can an attacker provide conflicting address assignments that cause earlier legitimate addresses to be overwritten with attacker-controlled values? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: unify_addresses_in_package()] [Global Pool Pollution] Addresses are added to global_named_address_pool with Rc::clone - can an attacker exploit shared Rc references to modify addresses in the global pool after they've been distributed to multiple packages? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: unify_addresses_in_package()] [RefCell Borrowing Panic] When calling other.unify(), the implementation uses borrow_mut() on RefCell - can an attacker trigger scenarios where the RefCell is already borrowed, causing panic and validator crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: unify_addresses_in_package()] [Dev Address Injection] In dev_mode, dev_address_assignments are processed - can an attacker craft dev addresses that override critical system addresses only in dev builds, hiding vulnerabilities that appear in production? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: unify_addresses_in_package()] [Unbound Address Bypass] The code bails if dev address is not in resolution_table, but can an attacker insert the name with None value first to bypass this check, then assign malicious address later? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: unify_addresses_in_package()] [Uniqueness Check Race] The addr_to_name_mapping is built from resolved addresses - can an attacker exploit race conditions in concurrent resolution to bypass the uniqueness check for dev address assignments? (Medium)
